questions.text:
1. An elderly man presents with acute pancreatitis. The results of the examination and investigations are given below. According to the BISAP scoring system, the presence of which of the following indicates a worse prognosis?

1) Age: 62 years 2) Blood Urea Nitrogen: 27 mg/dL 3) Serum lipase: 500 U/L 4) Hematocrit: 40% 5) Chest x-ray: Left-sided pleural effusion
questions.solution:
This patient with acute pancreatitis has 3 parameters ie an age > 60 , BUN> 25mg/dl and chest x-ray showing pleural effusion which are indicative of poor prognosis according to the BISAP score.

The severity of acute pancreatitis is determined to assist in patient triage. The Bedside Index of Severity in Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes five parameters obtained within the first 24 hours of hospitalization.

These are as follows: 

* BUN >25 mg/dL

* Impaired mental status (Glasgow coma scale score <15)

* SIRS

* Age >60 years

* Pleural effusion on radiography

The presence of three or more of these is associated with increased risk of in-hospital mortality among patients with acute pancreatitis. 

Other scoring systems Used for Acute Pancreatitis: 

* RANSON criteria

* HAPS (Harmless acute pancreatitis score)

* Revised Atlanta classification

Other options: 

Statement 3: Serum lipase is not part of the BISAP scoring system

Statement 4: An elevated hematocrit >44% is associated with more severe acute pancreatitis, but is not part of the BISAP scoring system. Also, this patient’s hematocrit is 40%.

Pearl PM1632: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

* Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:

* Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL

* Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15

* Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)

* Age > 60 years

* Pleural effusion One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.

* Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS) If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:

* Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding

* Normal hematocrit

* Normal serum creatinine

* Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)

* A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe

* Can be done at admission and repeated any time

* Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age

* Ranson’s score

* Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe

* Atlanta classification

questions.text:
3. A 50-year-old cirrhotic patient has been posted for a laparotomy procedure. He has encephalopathy and severe ascites. His pre-operative workup results are given below. According to the Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system, which class would the patient fall into?

Serum bilirubin: 3.2 mg/dl Serum albumin: 2.4 g/dl Prothrombin time: increased by 7 seconds INR: 2.5
questions.solution:
The Child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the patient described is Class C.

The points for:

* Serum bilirubin of 3.2mg/dl: 3

* Serum albumin of 2.4g/dl: 3

* INR of 2.5: 3

* Uncontrolled encephalopathy: 3

* Uncontrolled ascites: 3

Therefore the Child-Turcotte-Pugh class for the total points (3+3+3+3+3)= 15 is Class C.

Pearl PM1602: Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score

Child-Turcotte-Pugh class and overall surgical mortality rates:

* Class A = 5–6 points - Well-compensated - 10% mortality

* Class B = 7–9 points - Decompensated and significant  functional compromise - 30% mortality

* Class C = 10–15 points - Severerly decompensated - 75-80% mortality

questions.text: 4. A 46 year old female patient undergoes a mammography for a lump in the right breast. Based on the imaging report, she is advised to undergo a biopsy. Which of the following could have been reported?
questions.solution:
BIRADS-4 indicates 'suspicious for malignancy' and BIRADS-5 indicates 'highly suggestive of malignancy'.

A biopsy may be considered for patients with BIRADS-4 and is definitely indicated in patients with BIRADS-5.

Pearl PM1831: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

questions.text: 5. According to NADA's criteria, which of these findings would not be sufficient to consider the diagnosis of congenital heart disease in an infant?

choices.text: Presence of abnormal S2 and abnormal chest -X-ray
Presence of grade 3 systolic murmur alone

questions.solution:
According to NADA's criteria, the presence of abnormal ECG alone is not sufficient by itself to indicate congenital heart disease in an infant as it is a minor criteria. NADA’s criteria is used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children. The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.

Major criteria  Minor criteria
Systolic murmur grade 3 or more Systolic murmur < grade 3
Any diastolic murmur Abnormal second sound (S2)
Cyanosis Abnormal ECG
Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal chest X-ray findings
 

Abnormal BP

questions.text: 6. A 60-year-old woman presented with painful swelling of the right calf muscle, 7 days after her knee replacement surgery. On examination, her heart rate is 70 beats per min, her blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and her SPO2 is 96% on room air. The test shown below is positive. She has no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis. Calculate her modified Well's score for the risk of developing pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of deep venous thrombosis(DVT). The most common clinical presentation of DVT is pain and tenderness in the calf. The given image shows the method of eliciting Moses' sign, which is calf pain/tenderness on applying direct pressure over calf muscles seen in deep venous thrombosis (DVT). The Well's score in this patient is 7.5

In such patients who fall in the high-risk category, a combination of mechanical and pharmacological treatment with heparin should be initiated. 

Calculation of Modified Well's score in this case:

* Signs and symptoms of DVT = 3

* No alternative diagnosis = 3

* Heart rate is 70 beats per min. (<100) = 0

* Surgery in previous 4 weeks = 1.5

* No previous PE = 0

* No hemoptysis = 0

* No cancer (no significant weight loss) = 0

Total score = 7.5

Modified Wells criteria:

* PE likely >4

* PE unlikely
Well's criteria (Three-tiered clinical probability assessment):

* High risk >6

* Moderate risk 2-6

* Low risk <2

DVT is mostly unilateral, with an unreliable clinical examination. Some cases may present directly as pulmonary thromboembolism.

Deep vein thrombosis:

Causes

* Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause)

* Following childbirth

* Trauma- to leg, ankle, thigh, pelvis

* Immobility – Bed-ridden patients, individuals on long-duration air or bus travel (Traveller’s thrombosis).

* Debilitating illness, obesity, immobility, bed rest, pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives, estrogens.

Sites

* Pelvic veins—common

* Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (Common on the left side).

Features of DVT

* Fever-commonest

* Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf

* Positive Homan’s, Mose’s sign

* Inverted beer bottle sign/ champagne bottle sign

* Commonly it is asymptomatic

* Features of pulmonary embolism

Note:

Mose's sign- Squeezing of the relaxed calf muscles from side-to-side is also painful as the thrombosed deep veins in the calf are always tender and this test is known as Moses’ sign.

Homans sign - Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with the knee extended will elicit tenderness in the calf. Gentle pressure directly on the calf muscles in the relaxed position will also elicit pain. Care must be taken to be gentle in manipulation lest it may dislodge a clot and cause a pulmonary embolism. The image is attached below. 

Treatment

* Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with crepe bandage.

* Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, phenindione.

* Palma operation

* May-Husni operation

Pulmonary embolism is the commonest complication of deep vein thrombosis leading to death.



Pearl PM1655: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

 


Pearl PM2392: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1


Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6


Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 


 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

* Age <50 years

* Heart rate <100 bpm

* SpO2 ≥95%

* No unilateral leg swelling

* No hemoptysis

* No recent trauma or surgery

* No history of venous thromboembolism

* No use of hormonal therapy.

Pearl PM2291: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

* Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb

* Surgery like hip or knee replacement

* Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months

* Myocardial infarction within last 3 months

* Previous venous thromboembolism

* Infections and inflammatory bowel disease

* Autoimmune diseases:

* Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)

* SLE

* Inherited thrombophilias:

* Factor V leiden mutation

* Deficiency of antithrombin III

* Deficiency of protein C or protein S

* Hypercoagulable states:

* Pregnancy and postpartum period

* COPD

* Nephrotic syndrome

* Polycythemia vera

* Malignancies

* Iatrogenic:

* OCPs

* Hormone replacement therapy

* Chemotherapeutic drugs

* Insertion of central venous lines

* Varicose veins

* Prolonged car or air travel.

questions.text:
7. Sequentially arrange the following scoring systems in the ascending order of their respective maximum possible scores

* Glasgow coma scale

* Revised Trauma Score

* Abbreviated Injury Scale

* Injury Severity Score
questions.solution:
The respective possible score ranges are

* Glasgow coma scale - 3-15

* Revised Trauma Score - 0-12

* Abbreviated Injury Scale - 1-6

* Injury Severity Score - 3-75

Hence the ascending order of maximum possible scores would be - Abbreviated Injury Scale->Revised Trauma Score-> Glasgow coma scale-> Injury Severity Score.

The ISS is defined as the sum of squares of the highest Abbreviated Injury Scale grade in the three most severely injured body regions. Six body regions are defined, as follows: the thorax, abdomen and visceral pelvis, head and neck, face, bony pelvis and extremities, and external structures. Only one injury per body region is allowed. If any body-system has an unsurvivable injury (AIS = 6), the total score automatically becomes 75.

 The Injury severity score (ISS) ranges from 1 to 75, with severity groupings being defined as

* Minor injury (less than 9),

* Moderate injury (between 9 and 16),

* Serious injury (between 16 and 25), and

* Severe injury (more than 25)

Pearl PM1769: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

* Glasgow coma scale

* Respiratory rate

* Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

* Eye-opening

* Verbal response

* Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical


  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

* Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury

* Limb ischemia

* Shock

* Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

* Injury Severity Score

* Revised Trauma Score

* Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)

* Age

Pearl PM0343: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

* 13-15 represent mild injury

* 9-12 represent moderate injury

* Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT


 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT


 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT


Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

* GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.

* If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)

* In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

* A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used

* when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0


The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

* Half-hourly for 2 hours,

* Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,

* 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text:
9. A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a high-speed two-wheeler motor vehicle accident. Blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drips from both nostrils which increases on leaning forward. A CT scan reveals a fracture line passing through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, the upper part of the maxillary sinus, and the pterygoid plate. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?

CT: Computed tomography
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of a Le-Fort II fracture of the maxilla. 

Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture. It is characterized by a fracture line that passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, the upper part of the maxillary sinus, and pterygoid plates.

Clinically, patients present after high-speed trauma to the face. They may present with a visible deformity or elongation of the midface. There is malocclusion of teeth on attempting to bite. Palpation may reveal an unusually mobile maxilla. It may be associated with CSF(cerebrospinal fluid) rhinorrhea due to injury to the cribriform plate. 

Diagnosis requires an X-ray or CT scan, wherein findings such as hanging maxilla are present. 

Treatment required fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.

Pearl PM0946: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla

* Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates

* It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate

* Also called Guerin’s fracture. 

Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture

* Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates

* X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla

* It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment

* Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates

* It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: 10. A 62-year-old male patient comes to the hospital with left lower abdominal pain which radiates to the back. He also complains of increased bowel movements, nausea, fever on and off for 2 weeks, and bloody stool occasionally. On examination, the abdomen is tender and rigid. A barium enema was performed and showed a partial filling of the lumen which has a sawtooth appearance. The classification used to describe the severity of the condition is ______.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an elderly male patient with left lower abdominal pain radiating to the back, increased bowel movements, on-and-off fever occasional bloody stools, and sawtooth appearance on barium enema is likely to have diverticular disease. The tender and rigid abdomen suggest a perforation. The classification system used to describe the severity of such a condition is the Hinchey classification.

The Hinchey classification system is commonly used to describe the severity of diverticular disease complicated by perforation and is an additional tool that may be used to guide overall management. It consists of:

* Stage I: Small, confined pericolic or mesenteric abscess

* Stage II: Larger, walled-off pelvic abscess

* Stage III: Generalized purulent peritonitis

* Stage IV: Generalized fecal peritonitis

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. They occur due to increased intraluminal pressure and thus are a pulsion type of diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic or present with distension, flatulence, and a sensation of heaviness in the lower abdomen.

The diagnosis is confirmed by a colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema. The barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth (image below). In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.



A high-fiber diet reduces the incidence of diverticulosis. Antispasmodics can be prescribed to reduce intestinal spasms. Most cases of bleeding are self-limiting. If persistent bleeding is present, surgical, endoscopic, or radiological interventions can be done to reduce the bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: Shimada classification describes neuroblastoma as either favorable or unfavorable histology based on the degree of differentiation, the mitosis–karyorrhexis index, and the presence or absence of Schwannian stroma.

Option C: Forrest classification is used for endoscopic findings and rebleeding risks in peptic ulcer disease.

Option D: Bismuth-Corlette classification is used for bile duct tumors.

questions.text: 11. When the level of hardness of water is around 150-300 mg/L, it is classified as?
questions.solution:
Hard water has the hardness value of 3–6 (150–300 mg/ L).

The hardness of water is defined as soap destroying power of water.

* Causes of Hardness of water: 

* Calcium bicarbonate 

* Magnesium bicarbonate 

* Calcium sulphate 

* Magnesium sulphate 

* Hardness can be either:

* Temporary hardness- caused by carbonates compounds 

* Permanent hardness- caused by non carbonate compounds like sulphates, nitrates and chlorides

* It is expressed in terms of mEq/ L.  

* 1mEq/ L of hardness = 50 mg CaCO3  in one liter of water. 

Classification Level of Hardness (mEq/ L) 

Classification Level of Hardness  mEq/ L
Soft water < 1 (50 mg/ L)
Moderately hard water 1-3 (50-150 mg/ L)
Hard water 3-6 (150-300 mg/ L)
Very hard water > 6 (>300 mg/ L)


Softening of water is recommended at level of hardness >3 mEq/ L (>150 mg/ L of calcium carbonate).

questions.text: 12. A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth, had blue extremities and irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate was 40/min and there was grimace with some flexion of extremities. APGAR score for this newborn is _______
questions.solution:
APGAR score in this baby is 5.

In this baby

* Colour: Blue extremities - score 1

* HR < 100/min - score 1

* Grimace - score 1

* Some flexion of extremities - score 1

* Irregular respiration - score 1

Thus total score is 5.

At 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth of the infant, the 5 objective signs listed here are evaluated and each is given a score of 0, 1, or 2.

A total score of 10 indicates an infant in the best possible condition. An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

Pearl PM2195: APGAR score

questions.text: 13. A young patient comes to the emergency with pain in the right leg after falling from a height. The radiological image of his limb is shown below. What is the type of Salter-Harris physeal injury shown in this radiograph?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph(CT) shows a fracture line through the growth plate and the metaphysis of the lower end of tibia, sparing the epiphysis, this suggests Salter-Harris type II injury.

In a type II fracture, the fracture lies away from the joint. The fracture involves the physis and a triangle of metaphyseal bone (Thurston Holland sign). This type is the commonest type of epiphyseal injury in patients over 10 years of age.

Salter-Harris classified epiphyseal injuries into 5 types as mentioned below. Rang added the sixth type, where there is a peripheral physis lesion.

Pearl PM0704: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate


Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

* Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures

* Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate

* Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification

* Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: 14. During triaging of casualties from a building collapse, you find a patient who is able to walk but has sprained his ankle along with abrasions on the legs and a laceration on the face. You would classify him under:
questions.solution:
This patient is classified under the green code, according to triage color coding. In triage, green signifies low-priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.

Triage is done to categorize the need for priority of patients in cases of mass casualties. The aim of triage is the identify patients who would benefit the most by being treated earlier.

Priority Color Medical need Clinical status Examples
First (I) Red Immediate Critical, but likely to survive if treated early
  • Severe facial trauma
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Profuse external bleeding
  • Hemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed
  • Extradural hematomas
Second (II) Yellow Urgent Critical, likely to survive treated  within hours
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Ruptured abdominal viscus
  • Pelvic fractures
  • Spinal injuries
Third (III) Green Non-urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed hours- days
  • Simple fractures
  • Sprains
  • Minor lacerations
Last (0) Black Unsalvageable Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help
  • Severe brain damage
  • Very extensive burns
  • Major disruption/loss of chest or abdominal wall structures


Pearl PM0128: Triage Colour Coding



 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: 15. A patient comes with productive cough with yellow sputum and high-grade fever with chills for the past 4 days. He has increased tactile fremitus, dull notes on percussion of the right side, and crackles. A chest radiograph was performed and is shown below. The doctor uses a criteria to find out if the patient needs hospitalization or not. All of the following are the components of this criteria except:
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of fever, productive cough, increased tactile fremitus with crackles in the lung fields, and the radiograph indicates a diagnosis of lobar pneumonia. The need for hospitalization in this patient is assessed using the CURB 65 criteria. Consolidation is not a parameter included in this criteria.

CURB 65 scores for community-acquired pneumonia:

Clinical factor Points
Confusion  1
Blood urea nitrogen > 19 mg per dL 1
Respiratory rate ≥ 30 breaths per minute 1
Systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg or Diastolic blood pressure ≤ 60 mm Hg 1
Age ≥ 65 years 1 


Interpretation:

* Scores 0-1 are considered as low risk and home treatment can be considered

* Score 2 will require short inpatient hospitalization or closely supervised outpatient treatment

* Scores 3-5 are severe pneumonia. It will require hospitalization and admission to intensive care

Another similar criteria used in the assessment of the severity of pneumonia is CRB-65. Here the urea levels in the blood are not considered. The rest of the parameters are the same as those used in CURB-65. In this,

* Score 0 has a low risk of death and does not require hospitalization

* Score 1 and 2 have an increased risk of death and hospitalization is considered.

* Score 3 and 4 have a high risk of death and require urgent hospitalization.

Pearl PM1171: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

* Confusion 

* Urea (BUN) >7 mmol/L (20mg/dL)

* Respiratory rate ≥30/min 

* Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 

* Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

questions.text: 16. A patient is admitted to ICU following a road traffic accident. Your resident in ICU asks you to calculate his Glasgow coma scale (GCS). You notice that the patient's eyes are swollen due to injury and are unable to open. He is speaking single words. On applying stimulus to the neck, he brings his hand above the clavicle. What is the GCS score in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case,

* Eyes cannot be opened due to swelling- NT

* Verbal response- Able to speak 1-2 words- 3

* Motor response- The patient is able to localise the stimulus- 5

So, the GCS score in him is ENTV3M5

Glasgow coma scale (GCS)

Eye response (E)

Criterion Rating Score
Open before stimulus Spontaneous 4
After spoken or shouted request To sound 3
After finger tip stimulus Pressure 2
Not opening at any time (no interfering factor) None 1
Closed by a local factor Not testable  NT


Verbal response (V)

Correctly gives name, place, and date Oriented 5
Not oriented, but communication is coherent Confused 4
Speaks single words Words 3
Only moans or groans Sounds 2
No audible response (no interfering factor) None 1
Factor interfering with communication Not testable NT


Motor response (M)

Obeys commands Obeys commands 6
Brings hand above clavicle to stimulus on head neck Localising 5
Bends arm at elbow rapidly but features not predominantly abnormal Normal flexion 4
Bends arm at elbow features clearly predominantly abnormal Abnormal flexion 3
Extends arm at elbow Extension 2
No movement in arms/legs, no interfering factor None 1
Paralysed or other limiting factors Not testable NT


Note-

Sites or modes of physical stimulation are fingertip pressure, trapezium pinch and pressure on a supraorbital notch.

Normal flexion is rapid and away from the body, whereas abnormal flexion is a slow stereotyped movement with an arm across the chest. The forearm rotates, the thumb is clenched and the legs are in extension.

Pearl PM0343: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

* 13-15 represent mild injury

* 9-12 represent moderate injury

* Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

Do not open 1

Non-testable

Normal-oriented conversation 5

Motor Response Score

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

* GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.

* If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)

* In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

* A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used

* when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0


The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

* Half-hourly for 2 hours,

* Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,

* 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: 17. All of the following are the components of the biophysical profile except_____
questions.solution:
Respiratory rate is not a component of the biophysical profile.

Biophysical profile/Manning’s score:

Parameters Minimal Normal Criteria Score

Fetal breathing movements   ≥ 1 episode of rhythmic breathing lasting > 30 seconds. 2
Gross body movements   ≥ 3 discrete body/limb movements 2
Fetal muscle tone   ≥ 1 episode of active extension(limb or trunk) with return of flexion. 2
Amniotic fluid volume A pocket of amniotic fluid that measures at least 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 ×2 cm pocket) 2


* Observation for 30 minutes

* Normal score- 2; Abnormal- 0

questions.text: 18. A 2-year-old girl presents to you with severe pain abdomen. On examination icterus is present and a small lump is palpable at the right hypochondriac region. An abdominal CT was done and is as shown. Choose the correct option regarding the classification of this disease.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the CT showing a central dot sign is suggestive of Caroli's disease or type V choledochal cyst according to Todani classification.

Caroli’s Disease is an autosomal recessive condition of multifocal cystic dilatation of segmental intrahepatic bile ducts. According to Todani classification, it is classified as a type V choledochal cyst. USG may show dilated intrahepatic bile ducts in these individuals which may be associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis. The beaded appearance of intrahepatic bile ducts on HIDA scan and the central dot sign on the CT are characteristic findings associated with Caroli's disease. MRCP is the investigation of choice. Malignancy may complicate the disease in longstanding cases

The arrows in the image given below are pointing to the central dot sign.



Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. 

Choledochal cyst is classified by Todani into five types:

* Type I: is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.

* Type II: It is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD

* Type III: They arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct and are also known as choledochocele.

* Type IVA: The cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.

* Type IVB: These choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.

* Type V (Caroli’s disease): It consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Other options: The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define bile duct injuries.



Pearl PM1614: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: 19. You are an intern posted in the casualty ward. The casualty ward receives a call asking for arrangements to receive the patients of a road traffic accident that occurred nearby. The trauma PG wants you to assess the severity of the patients' condition. You check for eye-opening, motor response, and verbal response of the patients. Which of the following scores would not require these assessments for calculation?
questions.solution:
Assessment of eye-opening, motor response, and verbal response of the patients are not required in the calculation of Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS).

Eye-opening, motor response, and verbal response are components of Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score. GCS is a component of Revised Trauma Score (RTS) and RTS is a component of Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS). So, the assessment of the parameters listed in the question is required for the calculation of all these scores.

1. Glasgow coma scale(GCS) score:

* Eye-opening

* Verbal response

* Motor response

2. Revised Trauma Score (RTS):

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a well-studied physiologic scoring system that characterizes the injured patient’s condition by incorporating the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate. These scores have been of value for research purposes and have been successfully used to make triage decisions.

3. Injury Severity Score (ISS):

The Injury Severity Score (ISS) is calculated by summing the squares of the Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions. The ISS ranges from 1 to 75, with severity groupings being defined as minor injury (ISS less than 9), moderate injury (ISS between 9 and 16), serious injury (ISS between 16 and 25), and severe injury (ISS more than 25). 

4. Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS):

* Injury Severity Score (ISS)

* Revised Trauma Score (RTS)

* Age

* Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)

5. Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) :

The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is the most widely validated classification system. It takes into consideration the following:

* Energy that caused the injury, skeletal/soft tissue injury

* Limb ischemia

* Shock

* Patient’s age

A score of 7 or higher consistently predicted the need for amputation, whereas all limbs with initial scores of 6 or less remained viable in the long term.

Pearl PM1769: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

* Glasgow coma scale

* Respiratory rate

* Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

* Eye-opening

* Verbal response

* Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical


  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

* Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury

* Limb ischemia

* Shock

* Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

* Injury Severity Score

* Revised Trauma Score

* Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)

* Age

questions.text: 20. Your surgery resident classified a patient's wound as grade III according to the Southampton wound grading system. Which of the following features would you see in a patient classified under this grade?

choices.text: Considerable bruising plus hematoma requiring drainage
Erythema and swelling around the suture
Pus discharge at one point in the wound

questions.solution:
The features that will be seen in the grade III Southampton wound scoring system are clear or haemo serous discharge. It can be

* At one point only (< 2 cm)

* Along wound (>2 cm)

* Large volume

* Prolonged (>3 days)

Southampton wound grading system is a scoring system for the severity of wound infection:

Grade Appearance
0 Normal healing
I Normal healing with mild bruising or erythema
Ia Some bruising
Ib Considerable bruising
Ic Mild erythema
II Erythema plus other signs of inflammation
IIa At one point
IIb Around sutures
IIc Along wound
IId  Around wound
III Clear or haemoserous discharge
IIIa At one point only (< 2 cm)
IIIb Along wound (>2 cm)
IIIc Large volume
IIId Prolonged (>3 days)
Major complication
IV Pus
IVa At one point only (< 2 cm)
IVb Along wound (>2 cm)
V Deep or severe wound infection with or without tissue breakdown; Hematoma requiring aspiration
